question:
What will come in the place of the question mark (?) in the following equation, if '+' and ' - ' are interchanged and 'x' and '÷' are interchanged?

291 - 1606 x 11 + 13 ÷ 21 = ?
solution:
If '+' and ' - ' are interchanged and 'x' and '÷' are interchanged, then the equation will be: 291 + 1606 ÷ 11 - 13 x 21

So, 291 + 146 - 13 x 21 = ?

So, 291 + 146 - 273 = ?

So, 437 - 273 = ?

So, ? = 164

Similarly,

SKODA

After reversing = ADOKS

A+1D+1O+1K+1S+1SKODA
BEPLTBEPLT

Thus, the answer is option (b).

question: If, M % N means M is the daughter of N, M & N means M is the spouse of N, and M @ N means M is the father of N, then what does A % B & C % D & E @ G mean?
option_1: A is the granddaughter of G.
option_2: A is the niece of G.
option_3: A is the sister-in-law of G.
option_4: A is the daughter of G.
solution:
A % B & C % D & E @ G

A % B means A is the daughter of B

B & C means B is the spouse of C

C % D means C is the daughter of D

D & E means D is the spouse of E

E @ G means E is the father of G

A is the niece of G.


https://u1.oliveboard.in/exams/solution/oliveimg/p26786/image001.png
https://u1.oliveboard.in/exams/solution/oliveimg/p26786/image002.png

question:
In the question, three statements are given, followed by three conclusions, I, II and III. You have to consider the statements to be true even if they seems to be at variance from commonly known facts. You have to decide which of the given conclusions, if any, follow(s) from the given statements.

Statements:

All Roads are Street

Some Roads are Path

No Path is Line

Conclusions:

I. No Street is Line

II. Some Roads are not Line

III. Some Street is Path
option_2: Both conclusions I and II follow
option_4: Both conclusions II and III follow
solution:
Statements:

All Roads are Street

Some Roads are Path

No Path is Line

No Street is Line: There is no direct relation between Street and Line. SO, conclusion I does not follows.

Some Roads are not Line: Some Roads are Path. No Path is Line. Thus, the Roads which are Path is not Line. So, conclusion II follows.

Some Street is Path: All Roads are Street. Some Roads are Path. Thus, Some Street is Path. So, conclusion III follows.

Hence, Both conclusions II and III follow.

solution:
This box will look when unfolded:

A lies opposite to E; C lies opposite to F and B lies opposite to D.

Figure I: 1 lies opposite to 2; 5 lies opposite to 4; 6 lies opposite to 3. Thus 4 is not opposite to 5. So, this figure is incorrect.

Figure II: 5 lies opposite to 1; 6 lies opposite 3; 4 lies opposite to 2. Thus, this is a correct figure.

Figure III: 4 lies opposite to 5; 1 lies opposite to 3; 6 lies opposite to 2. Thus 4 is not opposite to 5. So, this figure is incorrect.

Figure IV: 1 lies opposite to 2; 5 lies opposite to 6; 3 lies opposite to 4. Thus 1 is not opposite to 2. So, this figure is incorrect.

question: 87 is related to 58 following a certain logic. Following the same logic, 96 is related to 64. Which of the following numbers is related to 16 using the same logic?
solution:
87 is related to 58. 96 is related to 64.

Here, the pattern is:

87 - 58 = 29 and we know that, 58 ÷ 2 = 29

96 - 64 = 32 and we know that, 64 ÷ 2 = 32

Similarly,

16 ÷ 2 = 8. So, 16 + 8 = 24

question:
Select the correct combination of mathematical signs to sequentially place from left to right in the blanks below to balance the given equation.

14_19_3_18_2 = 6
solution:
If the signs are sequentially place from left to right in the blanks, then the equations will be:

Option (a) 14 x 19 + 3 - 18 ÷ 2 = 6

266 + 3 - 9 = 6

269 - 9 = 6

260 ≠ 6

So, the equation is not balanced.

Option (b) 14 ÷ 19 + 3 - 18 x 2 = 6

0.73 + 3 - 36 = 6

3.73 - 36 = 6

-32.27 ≠ 6

So, the equation is not balanced.

Option (c) 14 - 19 + 3 x 18 ÷ 2 = 6

14 - 19 + 54 ÷ 2 = 6

14 - 19 + 27 = 6

41 - 19 = 6

22 ≠ 6

So, the equation is not balanced.

Option (d) 14 + 19 - 3 x 18 ÷ 2 = 6

14 + 19 - 54 ÷ 2 = 6

14 + 19 - 27 = 6

33 - 27 = 6

6 = 6

So, the equation is balanced.

question:
Select the option that represents the letters which, when placed from left to right in the blanks below, will complete the letter series.

%_O_L=%G_ _L=_G_A_=%_ _AL=
solution:
Option (a) When the blanks are replaced sequentially by the given letters, then the series will be: %%OGL=%G=OL=LG%AA=%LOAL=

Here, no definite pattern can be established. So, option (a) is incorrect.

Option (b) When the blanks are replaced sequentially by the given letters, then the series will be: %GOAL=%GOAL=%GOAL=%GOAL=

Here, the pattern '%GOAL=' is repeating.

Option (c) When the blanks are replaced sequentially by the given letters, then the series will be: %OOLL=%G=%L=GGAAA=%L=AL=

Here, no definite pattern can be established. So, option (c) is incorrect.

Option (d) When the blanks are replaced sequentially by the given letters, then the series will be: %OOAL=%GGOL=AGLA%=%=OAL=

Here, no definite pattern can be established. So, option (d) is incorrect.

question: If each letter of the word 'DYNAMICS' is arranged in the English alphabetical order from left to right, then in the English alphabetical series, which of the following vowels appears after the seventh letter from the left end?
solution:
The word is DYNAMICS.

All letters are arranged in the English alphabetical order, then we get: ACDIMNSY.

The seventh letter from the left end is 'S'.

So, the vowel 'U' appears after the alphabet 'S' in the English alphabetical series.

question: If a 12-year-old is found to be working in a factory manufacturing carpets, which of the following Articles of the Constitution of India will be violated?
solution:
If a 12-year-old is found working in a carpet manufacturing factory, Article 24 of the Constitution of India will be violated.

Article 24: Prohibition of employment of children in factories etc.

- No child below the age of fourteen years shall be employed in work in any factory or mine or engaged in any other hazardous employment.

Further insights:

Article 25: Freedom of Conscience and Right to Freely Profess, Practice and Propagate Religion

Article 26: Freedom to Manage Religious Affairs

Article 23: Prohibition of Traffic in Human Beings and Forced Labour

question: Financing for micro, small and medium enterprises are predominantly done by _______.
solution:
Small Industries Development Bank of India (SIDBI) finances micro, small and medium enterprises. It is headquartered in Lucknow.

It was was established under an Act of the Parliament in 1990.

SIDBI is a key institution dedicated to the promotion and financing of MSMEs in India. It provides a range of financial products and services, including:

-Direct Loans: To MSMEs for various purposes like working capital, term loans, and equipment finance.

- Refinance: To banks and other financial institutions that lend to MSMEs.

- Equity Participation: In MSME ventures.

- Credit Guarantee Schemes: To reduce the risk for lenders and encourage lending to MSMEs.

Further insights:

FSDC:

- Financial Stability and Development Council (FSDC) is an apex-level body constituted by the government of India. The idea to create such a super regulatory body was first mooted by the Raghuram Rajan Committee in 2008.

- The Council deals, inter-alia, with issues relating to financial stability, financial sector development, inter-regulatory coordination, financial literacy, financial inclusion and macro prudential supervision of the economy including the functioning of large financial conglomerates. No funds are separately allocated to the Council for undertaking its activities.

NABARD (National Bank for Agriculture and Rural Development): NABARD provides loans and support to banks that lend money to farmers, helps improve agriculture, and works on rural development projects.

PFRDA (Pension Fund Regulatory and Development Authority): This organization is responsible for regulating pension funds in India. It ensures that pension funds are managed properly and that people's retirement savings are safe and secure.

question: Which of the following festivals is associated with Telangana?
solution:
· Bonalu is a Hindu Festival where Goddess Mahakali is worshiped.

· It is an annual festival celebrated in the twin Cities Hyderabad and Secunderabad and other parts of Telangana state, India.

· Bonalu is celebrated usually during Ashada Masam that falls in July/August. Special poojas are performed for goddess Yellamma during the first and last day of the festival.

· The festival is considered as a form of thanksgiving to the Goddess after the fulfillment of vows.

· Bonam literally means Meal in Telugu, which is an offering to the Mother Goddess.

Further insights:

Gudi Padwa: A spring festival marking the traditional new year for Marathi Hindus. It is celebrated with a special flag called "Gudi" and festive food.

Bundi Utsav: A vibrant festival celebrated in Bundi, Rajasthan, known for its colorful processions, folk music, and dance performances.

Matho Narang: A unique festival celebrated in the Kumaon region of Uttarakhand, where people exchange oranges (Narang) as a symbol of friendship and goodwill.

question:
Identify the INCORRET statement(s) about the "Mansabdar".

A. The term mansabdar refers to an individual who holds a mansab, meaning a position or rank.

B. Rank and salary were determined by a numerical value called iqtas.
solution:
The term mansabdar refers to an individual who holds a mansab, meaning a position or rank.

It was a grading system used by the Mughals to fix (1) rank, (2) salary and (3) military responsibilities.

· Rank and salary were determined by a numerical value called zat.

· The higher the zat, the more prestigious was the noble's position in court and the larger his salary.

· The mansabdar's military responsibilities required him to maintain a specified number of sawar or cavalrymen.

· The mansabdar brought his cavalrymen for review, got them registered, their horses branded and then received money to pay them as salary.

· Mansabdars received their salaries as revenue assignments called jagirs which were somewhat like iqtas.

question: What is the chemical formula of Potash Alum?
solution:
Potash alum, Potash alum, also known as potassium aluminum sulfate, is a chemical compound with the formula KAl(SO₄)₂12H₂O.

It's a double sulfate mineral that includes both potassium and aluminum. It typically appears as colorless, transparent crystals or a white powder.

Others:

Carnallite: KCl. MgCl2 . 6H2O

Mohr's salt: FeSO4 . (NH4 ) 2SO4 . 6H2O

question: The term 'Tee' is related to which sports?
solution:
'Tee' is related to Golf.

Some other terms related to golf- birdie, bogey, lie, tee, rough.

Further insights:

Hockey: Penalty Corner, Backhand, Smash, Drag Flick, Free Hit

Boxing: Knockout, Uppercut, Jab, Hook, Referee

Billiards: Cue Ball, Red Ball, Break, Snooker, Pot

question: Who among the following was an Indian musician credited with popularizing the shehnai, a subcontinental wind instrument of the oboe class?
solution:
Ustad Qamruddin "Bismillah" Khan (born as Qamaruddin Khan), often referred to by the title Ustad, was an Indian musician credited with popularizing the shehnai, a subcontinental wind instrument of the oboe class. While the shehnai had long held importance as a folk instrument played primarily [schooled] in traditional ceremonies, Khan is credited with elevating its status and bringing it to the concert stage.

Sangeet Natak Akademi, New Delhi, instituted the Ustad Bismillah Khan Yuva Puraskar in 2007, in his honour. It is given to young artists in the field of music, theatre and dance.

question: The Kamet peak is located in ________
solution: Kamet is the second highest mountain in the Garhwal region of Uttarakhand, India, after Nanda Devi. It lies in the Chamoli District of Uttarakhand. Its appearance resembles a giant pyramid topped by a flat summit area with two peaks.

question: Black soils in India lack in:
solution: Chemically, the black soils are rich in lime, iron, magnesia and alumina. They also contain potash. But they lack in phosphorous, nitrogen and organic matter. The colour of the soil ranges from deep black to grey.

question: Which of the following belongs to mammal group in animal kingdom?
solution:
· Mammals include humans and all other animals that are warm-blooded vertebrates (vertebrates have backbones) with hair.

· Examples of mammals include rats, cats, dogs, deer, monkeys, apes, bats, whales, dolphins, and humans.

question: Who among the following has given the Sea Floor Spreading Theory?
solution:
· Sea Floor Spreading Theory was given by Harry Hess in 1960. He argued that floor of the ocean spreads due to constant eruptions at the crest of the oceanic ridges which causes the rupture of the oceanic crust.

· Alfred Wegner propounded the Continental Drift Theory in 1915 to explain the origin and evolution of the continents and oceans.

question: Taziya,made in numerous forms and types, is an important part of the ______celebrations.
solution: An important part of the Muharram celebrations of Muslims as well as non-Muslims, taziya,made in numerous forms and types, is a replica of the mausoleum of Imam Hussain , the grandson of Prophet Muhammad Taziya can be brought home on any day between the eve of the first day of Muharram and the ninth day and buried on the tenth day known as Ashoora, when Imam Hussain was martyred in AD 680 along with over 100 of his companions in the battle of Karbala fought against the army of Yazid, the then ruler of Syria,

question: Prices of similar products by different firms being identical is a result of
solution:
Perfect competition refers to a market that has many buyers and sellers, many similar products, and many substitutes and hence prices of similar products by different firms are identical.

In perfect competition:

- Many Sellers: There are numerous small firms, each with a negligible market share.

- Homogeneous Products: All firms produce identical products with no differentiation.

- Free Entry and Exit: Firms can easily enter or exit the market.

- Perfect Information: Buyers and sellers have complete and perfect information about market prices and conditions.

Further insights:

Monopoly is a market structure where a single seller dominates the market for a particular product or service. This single seller, often called a monopolist, has significant control over the price and quantity of the product.

Monopolistic Competition: A market structure characterized by many sellers offering differentiated products. Examples include restaurants, clothing stores, and hair salons.

Oligopoly: A market structure dominated by a few large firms. Examples include the automobile industry, the airline industry, and the telecommunications industry.

question: Which of the following is the only tripartite organization of the United Nations (UN)?
solution: The International Labour Organization (ILO) deals with labour issues. Its headquarters are in Geneva, Switzerland. Founded in 1919, it was formed through the negotiations of the Treaty of Versailles and was initially an agency of the League of Nations. It is the only tripartite United Nations (UN) agency. It brings together governments, employers, and workers of 187 member States (India is a member), to set labour standards, develop policies and devise programmes promoting decent work for all women and men.

question: Who is the author of the book "Our History, Their History, Whose History?"?
solution:
Professor Romila Thapar's 'Our History, Their History, Whose History?' released in 2023 is a profound statement on India's ongoing engagements with the past.

Other books of Romila Thapar:

Aśoka and the Decline of the Mauryas, 1961 (revision 1998)

A History of India: Volume 1, 1966

Ancient India, Medieval India, 1966, 1968 sq.; NCERT Textbooks

The Past and Prejudice (Sardar Patel Memorial Lectures), National Book Trust, 1975

Ancient Indian Social History: Some Interpretations, 1978

Exile and the Kingdom: Some Thoughts on the Rāmāyana, Rao Bahadur R. Narasimhachar Endowment lecture, 1978

Dissent in the Early Indian Tradition, Volume 7 of M.N. Roy memorial lecture, 1979

From Lineage to State: Social Formations of the Mid-First Millennium B.C. in the Ganges Valley, 1985

The Mauryas Revisited, Sakharam Ganesh Deuskar lectures on Indian history, 1987

Interpreting Early India, 1992 (2nd edition 1999); Oxford University Press 1999

Cultural Transaction and Early India: Tradition and Patronage, Two Lectures, 1994

Śakuntala: Texts, Readings, Histories, 2002

History and Beyond, 2000

Cultural Pasts: Essays in Early Indian History, 2003

Early India: From Origins to AD 1300, 2002

Somanatha: The Many Voices of History

India: Historical Beginnings and the Concept of the Aryan, Essays by Thapar, et al., 2006

The Aryan: Recasting Constructs, Three Essays, 2008

The Past before Us: Historical Traditions of Early North India, 2013

The Past As Present: Forging Contemporary Identities Through History, 2014

Voices of Dissent: An Essay, 2020

The Future in the Past: Essays and Reflections, 2023

question: The thin life supporting stratum of earth's surface is called _____.
solution:
The thin life supporting stratum of earth's surface is called the Biosphere. It extends from a few kilometres into the atmosphere to the deep-sea vents of the ocean.

Further insights:

Hydrosphere: All the water on, above, and below the surface of the Earth.

Troposphere: The lowest layer of the Earth's atmosphere, where weather occurs.

Lithosphere: The rigid outermost shell of the Earth, consisting of the crust and the uppermost part of the mantle.

question: Sultan Mahmud of Ghazni was a contemporary of ______.
solution:
Sultan Mahmud of Ghazni was a contemporary of Rajendra Chola I. During his campaigns in the subcontinent he attacked the temples of defeated kings and looted their wealth and idols.

Sultan Mahmud was not a very important ruler at that time. But by destroying temples - especially the one at Somnath - he tried to win credit as a great hero of Islam.

In the political culture of the Middle Ages most rulers displayed their political might and military success by attacking and looting the places of worship of defeated rulers.

question: Which of the following Mahajanapadas was monarchical in nature?
solution:
There were sixteen Mahajanapadas out of which some were monarcheal in nature and some were republics. The sixteen mahajanapadas are - Anga, Magadha, Kasi, Kosala, Yajji, Malla, Chhedi, Yamsa, Kuru, Pancala, Maccha, Surasena, Assaka, Avanti, Gandhara, and Kamboja.

• Mahajanapadas which were monarchial in nature- Gandhara, Kamboja, Kashi, Vatsa, Avanti, Chedi, Kuru, Panchala, Matsya, Anga, Kosala, Magadha and Surasena.

• Mahajanapadas which were republics -Assaka, Malla & Vajji.

question: Maxwell's equations are a set of four equations that are related to_______
option_1: movement of planets with respect to sun
option_3: behaviour of electric and magnetic fields
option_4: amount of heat generated in a closed system
solution: Maxwell's equations are a set of four equations that describe the behavior of electric and magnetic fields and how they relate to each other. Ultimately they demonstrate that electric and magnetic fields are two manifestations of the same phenomenon.

question: Which of the following Article of the Constitution of India provides power to the President for promulgating ordinances?
solution:
The President of India may enact ordinances under Article 123 of the Indian Constitution.

This article states that the President may promulgate an ordinance even while the Parliament is not in session if he is certain that circumstances exist that need him to act immediately.

Although the ordinance must be presented to both Houses of Parliament and expires six weeks after the reassembly of Parliament or sooner if the Parliament does not accept it, it has the same power and effect as an act of Parliament.

Further insights:

Article 77: This article deals with the conduct of business of the Government of India. It states that all executive actions of the Government of India shall be expressed to be taken in the name of the President.

Article 111: This article deals with the presentation of Bills in Parliament. It states that a Bill shall not be deemed to have been passed by the Houses of Parliament unless it has been presented to the President and has received his assent. The President may give his assent to the Bill, withhold his assent, or return the Bill for reconsideration.

Article 143: This article deals with the powers of the Supreme Court to advise the President on any matter of public importance. The President may consult the Supreme Court on any question of law or fact which he may refer to it. The Supreme Court shall give its opinion on the matter referred to it.

question: The States Reorganisation act was passed in the year _____.
solution:
An Act to provide for the reorganisation of the States of India and for matters connected therewith also known as States Reorganisation act was passed in the year 1956.

The States Reorganisation Act, 1956 was a major reform that reorganized the boundaries of India's states and territories, primarily along linguistic lines.

Key Features:

Redefined State Boundaries: It created 14 states and 6 union territories based on language, replacing the previous system of Part A, B, C, and D states.

Formation of New States: States like Andhra Pradesh, Kerala, and Maharashtra were formed based on linguistic demands.

Abolition of Rajpramukhs: The Act abolished the position of Rajpramukhs (rulers of princely states) who governed some states before.

Establishment of Zonal Councils: It established five zonal councils to promote inter-state cooperation and regional development.

question: In which year did the Central Consumer Protection Authority notify the "Guidelines for Prevention and Regulation of Dark Patterns"?
solution:
the Central Consumer Protection Authority notified the Guidelines for Prevention and Regulation of Dark Patterns in 2023 and specified 13 dark patterns, namely: False urgency, Basket Sneaking, Confirm shaming, forced action, Subscription trap, Interface Interference, Bait and switch, Drip Pricing, Disguised Advertisements and Nagging, Trick Wording, Saas Billing and Rogue Malwares.

In news:

Department of Consumer Affairs launched 'Jago Grahak Jago App,' revamped 'Jagriti App,' and 'Jagriti Dashboard' for public use on National Consumers Day 2024 i.e. 24th December, 2024.

question: The Finance Commission of India is constituted by the President every __________ years to recommend the distribution of financial resources between the Union and the States. The recommendations of the Finance Commission are binding on the __________.
solution:
Article 280: - Finance Commission

· The President shall, within two years from the commencement of this Constitution and thereafter at the expiration of every fifth year or at such earlier time as the President considers necessary, by order constitute a Finance Commission which shall consist of a Chairman and four other members to be appointed by the President.

· Parliament may by law determine the qualifications which shall be requisite for appointment as members of the Commission and the manner in which they shall be selected.

question: Shruti Sadolikar Katkar is a renowned Khayal singer from _______Gharana.
solution: Shruti Sadolikar Katkar is a Khayal singer from Jaipur-Atrauli Gharana, who bagged the Sangeet Natak Akademi Award for Hindustani vocal music in 2011.

question: Who won the 2024 Women's Asian Champions Trophy, a biennial women's international field hockey competition?
solution:
The 2024 Women's Asian Champions Trophy was the eighth edition of the Women's Asian Champions Trophy, a biennial field hockey tournament where the six best Asian women's national teams compete.

The hosts India were the defending champions. They defended their title by defeating China 1-0 in the final to win their third title.

The edition took place in Rajgir, India, from 11 to 20 November 2024. This was the second time, and the second consecutive time India hosted the Women's Asian Champions Trophy.

question: Find the area of the sector of a circle whose arc length and radius are 33 cm and 14 cm respectively.
solution: Area of sector = (1/2) * arc length * radius = (1/2) * 33 * 14 = 231 sq. cm

question: A train passes a station in 1 minute and 2 seconds and the speed of the train is 162 km/hr speed. If the length of the station is 1350 m, then find the time taken by the train to pass an electric pole.
solution:
Time = 1 * 60 + 2 = 62 seconds

Let the length of the train be 'L' m.

Speed of train = 162 * 5/18 = 45 m/s

Time = distance/ speed

62 seconds = (1350 + L)/ 45

1350 + l = 2790

l = 1440

time taken by the train to pass an electric pole = 1440/ 45 = 32 seconds

question: Two sides of a triangle are 12 cm and 16 cm long. If the length of the third side of the triangle is 'X' cm, then X:
solution:
The range of X is,

(16 - 12) < X < (16 + 12)

4 < X < 28

question: A boat covers 240 km downstream in 8 hours and 180 km upstream in 15 hours. Find the ratio of the speed of the stream to the speed of the boat.
solution:
Downstream speed = 240/8 = 30 km/hr

Upstream speed = 180/15 = 12 km/hr

Speed of the stream : speed of the boat = (Downstream - Upstream)/2 : ( Downstream + Upstream)/2

Speed of the stream : speed of the boat = (30 - 12)/2 : (30 + 12)/2 = 9 : 21 = 3 : 7

question:
The table below provides information about the price (in Rs.) of some number of articles sold by a shopkeeper.

PriceNumber of articles
Less than Rs.104
Less than Rs.2010
Less than Rs.3012
Less than Rs.4016
Less than Rs.5020

The price of how many articles is at least Rs.30 but less than Rs.40?
solution:
Number of articles of price at least Rs.30 but less than Rs.40 = Number of articles of price less than Rs.40 - Number of articles of price less than Rs.30

= 16 - 12 = 4

question:
Find the possible values of 'a' for which the following system of equations has no solutions.

(9a - 5)x + (7a + 3)y - 12 = 0 and 2ax + (a + 4)y - 13 = 0
The diameter of a hemisphere is 28 cm. If the volume of the hemisphere is equal to the volume of a cone and the height of the cone is 7 cm, then find the radius of the cone.
solution:
Radius of hemisphere = 28/2 = 14 cm

The volume of the hemisphere = The volume of the cone

=> 2/3 * π * (radius of hemisphere)3 = 1/3 * π * (radius of cone)2 * h

=> 2 * 14 * 14 * 14 = r2 * 7

=> r2 = 784

=> r = 28 cm

question: After giving a 20% discount on the marked price there is 60% of profit. If the discount is increased by 5% points, then find the profit percentage.
solution:
Let marked price = Rs.100

Discount% = 20%

So, selling price = 100 * (100 - 20)/100 = Rs.80

Profit% = 60%

Cost price = 80 * 100/160 = Rs.50

Now discount% = 25%

So, selling price = 100 * 75/100 = Rs.75

Cost price = Rs.50

Profit% = (75 - 50)* 100/50 = 25 * 2 = 50%.

question:
If tan β =
12_________17
, β is an acute angle, then find the value of
(3 - 3sinβ) (1 + sinβ)_________(1 - cosβ) (3 + 3cosβ)
solution:
[(3 - 3sinβ) (1 + sinβ)]/ [(1 - cosβ) (3 + 3cosβ)]

= [3 (1 - sinβ) (1 + sinβ)]/ [(1 - cosβ) 3 (1 + cosβ)]

= [(1 - sinβ) (1 + sinβ)]/ [(1 - cosβ) (1 + cosβ)]

= (1 - sin2β)/ (1 - cos2β) [(a - b)(a + b) = a2 - b2]

= cos2β/ sin2β [sin2θ + cos2θ = 1]

= cot2β

= 289/144

question: Rs 11,720 is divided amongst Lakshmi, Mittal and Narendra in such a manner that if Rs 100, Rs 125 and Rs 55 is added to their shares respectively, the ratio of their shares will become 8:9:3. What is the difference between Lakshmi's and Mittal's shares?
solution:
Let the shares of Lakshmi, Mittal and Narendra after adding the amounts be Rs 8k, Rs 9k and Rs 3k respectively.

So, (8k - 100) + (9k - 125) + (3k - 55) = 11720

20k = 12000

k = 600

Lakshmi's share = 4800 - 100 = 4700

Mittal's share = 5400 - 125 = 5275

Difference between Lakshmi's and Mittal's shares = 5275 - 4700 = Rs 575

question: Find the remainder, when (1956)165 is divided by 23.
solution:
When 1956 is divided by 23, remainder will be 1.

Using remainder theorem -

(1956)165/23

= (1)165/23

= 1/23

Remainder = 1

question: Simple interest on a sum at 77⁄9% rate per annum for 24⁄7 years is Rs.472. Calculate the sum.

Candidate A received 8500 of valid votes and won by a margin of 5750 votes. If 25% of the total casted votes were invalid votes out of a total of 15000 casted votes , what was the number of votes received by Candidate B?
solution:
Total voted casted = 15000

Percentage of valid votes = 100 - (20 + 5) = 75%

Total valid votes = 75% of 15000 = 11250

Number of votes received by B = 11250 - 8500 = 2750

question: Find the total numbers between 132 and 111. [including 132 and 111]
solution: Total numbers between 132 and 111 = 169 - 111 + 1 = 58 + 1 = 59

question: If the volume of a cuboid is A2 cubic units and the area of the base of cuboid is (100/A) square units, then find the height of cube.
solution:
Volume of cuboid = Area of base * height

Height = A2/ (100/A)

Height = A3/100 = A3 * 10-2 units.

question: A and B can complete a piece of work in 14 days and 20 days respectively. Find the time taken to complete the work if A and B work on alternate days starting from B.
solution:
Total work = LCM of 14 and 20 = 140 units

Efficiency of A = 140/14 = 10 units

Efficiency of B = 140/20 = 7 units

Part of work got completed in 2 days = 10 + 7 = 17 units

Part of work got completed in 16 days = 136 units

Remaining work will be completed by B in 4/7 days.

Total time = 16 (4/7) days

FamiliesRiceWheatPulse
P243528
Q124030
R183220
S93625
T122518

What is the total monthly usage of Rice and Wheat together in families Q and S together?
solution:
Total monthly usage of Rice and Wheat together in family Q = 12 + 40 = 52 kg

Total monthly usage of Rice and Wheat together in family S = 9 + 36 = 45 kg

Required monthly usage of Rice and Wheat = 52 + 45 = 97 kg

question: The angle of elevation of a ladder leaning against a house is 60° and the foot of the ladder is 29.5 meters from the house. What is the length of the ladder?
solution:
AB = Height of house

BC = distance between house and foot of the ladder

AC = Length of the ladder

1 = 29.5 m

2 = 59 m

Hence, the length of the ladder = 59 m

question: The average of 4 terms is 30 and the first term is 1/3 of the sum of the remaining terms. Find the first term.
If the circumradius of an equilateral triangle is 12 cm. Find the measure of its in-radius (in cm).
solution:
For an equilateral triangle circumradius(C) = 2 * In-radius(r)

R = 2r

12 = 2r

r = 6 cm

question:
Select the most appropriate ANTONYM of the given word.

Ample
solution:
Ample: generous or more than adequate in size, scope, or capacity.

Insufficient: not enough in amount, strength, or quality.

As per the meanings, 'insufficient' is the correct antonym. Hence, option (c) is the answer.

Abundant: present in great quantity; more than adequate.

Precise: exactly or sharply defined or stated.

Latent: existing in hidden or dormant form.

question:
Complete the following collocation.

He _____ a question during the meeting that sparked a lively discussion.
solution:
"Raised a question" is a commonly used phrase to indicate bringing up or introducing a question for consideration. It often implies initiating a discussion or prompting further exploration of a topic. Hence, (c) is the correct answer.

The final sentence would be: He raised a question during the meeting that sparked a lively discussion.

question:
Select the most appropriate option to fill in the blank.

None of the _____________ pointing towards the criminality of the accused person.
solution:
'Evidence' is an uncountable noun. It doesn't have a plural form. Thus, options (a) and (c) are incorrect.

When "none" is used with an uncountable noun, it agrees with a singular verb.

For example: none of the work is done. (When "work" is used as an uncountable noun)

Hence, option (b) is also incorrect.

Thus, the correct option is (d) evidence is

Thus, the correct sentence should be: None of the evidence is pointing towards the criminality of the accused person.

Additional Information:

When "none" is used with a countable noun, it agrees with both singular and plural verbs.

None of the actors are ready for the shoot. (Correct)

None of the actors is ready for the shoot. (Correct)

Uncountable nouns are nouns that cannot be counted or usually are not counted, for example, light, water, milk, information, furniture, etc. They do not generally have a plural form and can't be preceded by 'a' or 'an'. Many abstract nouns are typically uncountable. Some uncountable nouns can be used in the plural as well, depending on the meaning or context of the word.

question:
Select the option that expresses the given sentence in active voice.

In an unexpected moment, Rajan has been surrounded by the mob.
option_1: The mob has surrounded Rajan, in an unexpected moment.
option_2: The mob had surrounded Rajan, in an unexpected moment.
option_3: The mob have surrounded Rajan, in an unexpected moment.
option_4: The mob has been surrounding Rajan, in an unexpected moment.
solution:
The subject of the Passive Voice is changed into the object of the Active Voice. Also, the object of the Passive Voice is changed into the subject of the Active Voice.

The removal of the "to be" verb ['been' here] and the preposition 'by' is necessary while changing the voice of the sentence from Passive to Active.

The Passive voice in this question is in Present Perfect tense. Thus, the Active voice will also be in Present Perfect.

In Passive voice, the format is: Object of the Active voice (Subjective case) + has/have + been + V3 + by + Subject of the Active voice (Objective case).

Thus, the format of Active voice is: Subject + has/have + V3 + Object.

For example:

A new horse has been bought by Arya. (Passive Voice)

Arya has bought a new horse. (Active Voice)

The options except (a) don't follow the correct grammatical format of the Active Voice.

Hence, the correct answer is option (a).

Note:

V1 -> Base form/simple form of verb, V2 -> Past form of verb (-ed form or irregular verb), V3 -> Past participle form of verb (-ed, -d, -t, -en, or -n), V4 -> Continuous form of verb / Present participle form of verb (-ing form), V5 -> Third person singular (V1+ -es or -s).

A Preposition is a word placed before a noun or a pronoun or a noun equivalent (pronoun, adverb, gerund, infinitive, adverbial clause, or any clause that can be used as the object of the preposition) and shows a relationship in space or time or a logical relationship between two or more people, places, or things in a sentence.

Examples

I. The teacher scolded the child for being late.

II. We're going to a party.

· The words in bold are called prepositions because they normally take position before (pre) a noun/pronoun or a noun equivalent (pronoun, adverb, gerund, infinitive, adverbial clause, or any clause that can be used as the object of the preposition.

· The noun/pronoun which is used with a preposition is called its Object.

question:
Directions:

Directions [Set of 5 Questions]:In the following passage, some words have been deleted. Read the passage carefully and select the most appropriate option to fill in each blank.

Traveling is an exhilarating __ (1) __ that opens up a world of possibilities. It transports us to new landscapes, cultures, and perspectives, broadening our __ (2) __. The thrill of exploring unfamiliar places, tasting exotic cuisines, and meeting __ (3) __ people is unmatched. Each journey we embark upon unravels a tapestry of stories and memories that become a part of our own unique __ (4) __. Whether it's wandering through bustling city streets or immersing ourselves in nature's tranquillity, travel enriches our souls and fuels our wanderlust, reminding us that the world is an awe-inspiring place waiting to be __ (5) __.



Select the most appropriate option to fill in the blank No. 1.
solution:
The sentence with blank 1 talks about how travelling opens up ample possibilities. Among the given options, 'experience' fits in the blank appropriately as its usage conveys that travelling is an event which brings with it a lot of opportunities. Hence, (b) is the correct answer.

The rest of the options render the sentence meaningless.

Courtship- The act of attempting to win a person's favour or support.

If you have the gift of the gab, you can come out of many complex situations in life.

The rest of the meanings are contextually incorrect.

Therefore, the correct answer is: (c) art of speaking confidently.

question:
Select the most appropriate synonym of the given word from the sentence.

Mellifluous

The singing is impressive; vocal lines are challenging, athletic rather than mellow, often very high and requiring sharp characterization.
solution:
Mellifluous - (of a sound) pleasingly smooth and musical to hear.

Mellow - (especially of a sound, flavour, or colour) pleasantly smooth or soft; free from harshness.

Both words are similar in meaning. Hence, option (c) is the answer.

Challenging - testing one's abilities; demanding.

Impressive - evoking admiration through size, quality, or skill; grand, imposing, or awesome.

Athletic - physically strong, fit, and active.

question:
Select the option that expresses the given sentence in passive voice.

You should do this task or you will be fired by us.
option_1: This task should be done by you or we will fire you.
option_2: You should do this task or we will fire you.
option_3: Let this task be done or you would be fired.
option_4: This task should have been done by you or we will fire you.
solution:
· The correct answer is (a) This task should be done by you or we will fire you.

· The subject of the Active Voice is changed into object of the Passive voice. Also, the object of the Active Voice is changed is changed into subject of the Passive Voice.

· The usage of a helping verb is necessary while changing the voice of the sentence from Active to Passive.

· Preposition "by" is used before the object made in Passive Voice. However, it is optional in some cases.

· These types of questions contain Modal verbs and they should be used correctly as stated below.

· Modal verbs can be identified by the following:

o Can

o Could

o May

o Might

o Shall

o Should

o Will

o Would

o Must

o Ought to

· The format of sentences containing Modal verbs in Active voice is: Subject + Modal + V1 + Object.

· Thus, in Passive voice, the format will be: Subject (Objective case) + Modal + be + V3 + by + Object (Subjective case).

· For example:

o You can do this. (Active Voice)

o This can be done by you. (Passive Voice)

· The options except (a) don't follow the correct grammatical format of the Passive Voice.

· Therefore, the correct answer is: This task should be done by you or we will fire you.

V1 -> Base form/simple form of verb, V2 -> Past form of verb (-ed form or irregular verb), V3 -> Past participle form of verb (-ed, -d, -t, -en, or -n), V4 -> Continuous form of verb / Present participle form of verb (-ing form), V5 -> Third person singular (V1+ -es or -s)

question: Select the INCORRECTLY spelt word.
solution: The correct spelling of the fourth word is 'radius'. Option D is the correct answer. 'Realm'- a field or domain of activity or interest

question:
Select the most appropriate ANTONYM of the given word.

Former
solution:
'Former' means previous. 'Latter' means being the second of two items. So, the two words can be used as antonyms of each other. Hence, (b) is the correct answer.

'Before' means earlier than in time.

'Back' means returned to a previous place or condition.

'Furious' means feeling violent.

question:
Parts of a sentence are given below in jumbled order. Arrange the parts in the correct order to form a meaningful sentence.

The ashrams / used / were / the centres / of / knowledge and learning / as
option_1: The ashrams were used as the centres of knowledge and learning.
option_2: As The ashrams of knowledge and learning were used the centres.
option_3: Knowledge and learning were used as the centres of the ashrams.
option_4: The centres of the ashrams were used as knowledge and learning.
solution:
'The ashrams' acts as the subject of the sentence. The subject will be followed by the helping verb and the main verb (i.e., 'were used'). The clause explaining how the ashrams were used will be connected to the former clause with the help of 'as'. What they were used as was 'the centres of knowledge and learning'.

So, the correct sentence is: The ashrams were used as the centres of knowledge and learning.

Hence, option (a) is the answer.

question:
Select the option that will improve the underlined part of the given sentence. In case no improvement is needed, select 'No improvement required'.

If everything goes right, he will be soon forget all about me.
solution:
The underlined part of the sentence is grammatically incorrect. 'Forget' is a base verb and we cannot use a base verb after 'be'.

The sentence structure of a conditional sentence of 'if' is if + simple present, will/can + base verb. Among the given options, option (d) is the only one that follows the correct syntax of the conditional sentence. Hence, option (d) is the correct answer.

question: Select the sentence with the appropriate use of preposition.
option_1: I just lay in the sun since a week and did nothing - it was heaven.
option_2: I just lay in the sun by a week and did nothing - it was heaven.
option_3: I just lay in the sun for a week and did nothing - it was heaven.
option_4: I just lay in the sun from a week and did nothing - it was heaven.
solution:
'A week' is a period of time. 'Since' cannot be used for a period of time. The preposition 'for' should be used before a period of time. E.g., I was waiting for an hour.

The preposition 'by' (which indicates the agent of action) does not fit in the sentence contextually.

The preposition 'from' (used to refer to the place where someone or something starts or originates) does not give any meaning to the sentence.

Hence, option (c) is the correct answer.

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.

The video which has been largely shared over social media has also accumulated over 14,000 likes for its release date.
option_4: over 14,000 likes for its release date
solution:
The word 'for' is used to show a period of time, be it in the past, present or future. We cannot use 'for' with a point of time (its release date) in the past. The word 'since' is used to refer to a time that has begun in the past and is still continuing. So, 'for' should be replaced with 'since' to rectify the given sentence. Therefore, the error is in the part in option (d).

The correct sentence is: The video which has been largely shared over social media has also accumulated over 14,000 likes since its release date.

Hence, option (d) is the correct answer.

question:
The following sentence has been divided into parts. One of them may contain an error. Select the part that contains the error from the given options.

Every tree grows/ in it's own unique way,/ contributing to the beauty/ and diversity of the forest.
solution:
The part that contains the error is 'in it's own unique way'. The error lies in the incorrect use of the contraction "it's". The word "it's" is a contraction of "it is" or "it has". However, in the given sentence, the intended meaning is to indicate possession, which requires the possessive form "its". "Its" is a possessive determiner used to indicate that something belongs to or is associated with something previously mentioned. In the sentence, "its" indicates possession, showing that each tree has its own specific and unique way of growing. Hence, (b) is the correct answer.

The correct sentence is: Every tree grows in its own unique way, contributing to the beauty and diversity of the forest.

NOTE:

Possessive Determiners/Adjectives: Words like 'my', 'our', 'your', 'his', 'her', 'its', and 'their' are known as possessive adjectives (or possessive determiners). They come before nouns and indicate ownership of the noun. Example: "The teacher asked the students to open their drawing books."

question:
Select the most appropriate ANTONYM of the given word.

Despair
solution:
'Despair' and 'gloom' mean the state of having lost all hope.

So, 'hope' is the right antonym.

Hence, option (c) is correct.

question: Select the INCORRECTLY spelt word.
solution:
Option b) is incorrectly spelt. The correct spelling should be 'acknowledgement' (the act of showing that you have seen or noticed somebody/something).

Hence, option b) is the answer.

question:
Select the option that can be used as a one-word substitute for the underlined group of words.

The hostages are to be saved from the dangerous situation.
solution:
Gathered- come together

Rescued- save (someone) from a dangerous or difficult situation

Identified- recognize or distinguish

Informed- give (someone) facts or information

Among the given options, the word that matches the meaning of the underlined set of words is option (b) 'rescued'.

Hence, the correct answer is option (b).

question:
Select the most appropriate meaning of the underlined idiom in the given sentence.

Samrat's dog in a manger attitude is the reason why he doesn't have any good friends.
option_2: Lacking the ability to keep secrets
option_3: Preventing others from enjoying what he himself cannot.
solution:
Dog in a manger: a person who has no need of, or ability to use, a possession that would be of use or value to others, but who prevents others from having it.

It is in context to Samrat whose mentality of preventing others from enjoying what he himself cannot enjoy is the cause of his lack of good friends.

The rest of the meanings are contextually incorrect.

Therefore, the correct answer is (c), Preventing others from enjoying what he himself cannot.

question:
Select the most appropriate synonym of the given word.

Fascinating
solution:
Fascinating: extremely interesting or charming.

Enchanting: delightfully charming or attractive.

So, both words are similar in meaning. Hence, option (c) is the answer.

Encouraging: giving someone support or confidence; supportive.

Knowing: showing or suggesting that one has knowledge or awareness that is secret or known to only a few people.

Bustling: (of a place) full of activity.
